topic: scientists just got some ancient clues about future sea-level rise — and it’s bad news

text: Scientists have recently discovered ancient clues that provide insight into future sea-level rise, and the findings are concerning.

According to new research, during the last interglacial period, which occurred around 125,000 years ago, sea levels were significantly higher than they are today, due to the melting of ice sheets in Greenland and Antarctica.

By studying fossilized coral reefs and sediment cores, researchers have been able to reconstruct the extent of sea-level rise during this period, which is helping them better understand the potential impacts of climate change on sea levels in the future.
The data suggests that sea levels were around 6 meters higher than they are today, which is consistent with predictions of future sea-level rise due to global warming.
